deck.name: GCP PCA - Networking
deck.description: Networking architecture, Hybrid connectivity และ Load Balancing สำหรับ GCP Professional Cloud Architect

cards.vocab: How do you design VPC networks for enterprise?
cards.meaning: ออกแบบ VPC networks สำหรับ enterprise อย่างไร?
cards.example: Common patterns: 1) Shared VPC: Centralized network management. Host project owns VPC, service projects use subnets. Best for: Central IT control, consistent policies. 2) VPC Peering: Direct connection between VPCs. Non-transitive (A-B, B-C doesn't mean A-C). Best for: Cross-project connectivity, simple needs. 3) Hub-and-spoke: Central hub VPC, spokes connect via peering/VPN. Best for: Centralized services (NAT, firewall), inspection. Design considerations: IP address planning (avoid overlaps), subnet sizing, region placement, firewall rules (deny by default). Exam tip: Shared VPC for organization-wide control, understand non-transitive peering.

cards.vocab: How do you choose between hybrid connectivity options?
cards.meaning: เลือกระหว่าง hybrid connectivity options อย่างไร?
cards.example: Options comparison: 1) Cloud VPN: Over internet, encrypted, up to 3 Gbps/tunnel. Use when: Quick setup, <3Gbps needed, cost-sensitive. HA VPN for 99.99% SLA. 2) Dedicated Interconnect: Physical connection at colocation. 10/100 Gbps, 99.99% SLA with redundancy. Use when: >10 Gbps, low latency critical, consistent bandwidth. 3) Partner Interconnect: Via service provider. 50 Mbps - 50 Gbps. Use when: Can't reach colocation, need >3 Gbps but <10 Gbps. Decision factors: Bandwidth needs, latency requirements, cost, setup time. For encryption over Interconnect, use VPN tunnels on top. Exam tip: Know bandwidth limits, when Dedicated vs Partner Interconnect.

cards.vocab: How do you select the right load balancer?
cards.meaning: เลือก load balancer ที่เหมาะสมอย่างไร?
cards.example: Decision tree: 1) Internal or External traffic? Internal: Internal HTTP(S) LB (L7), Internal TCP/UDP LB (L4). External: Continue... 2) Global or Regional? Global (anycast IP, multi-region): Global HTTP(S) LB, SSL Proxy, TCP Proxy. Regional: Regional HTTP(S) LB, Network LB. 3) HTTP(S) or TCP/UDP? HTTP(S): Global/Regional HTTP(S) LB (L7 features). TCP/UDP: SSL Proxy, TCP Proxy, Network LB (L4). Key features by type: Global HTTP(S): URL routing, CDN, Cloud Armor, managed SSL. Network LB: Preserve client IP, high performance, no proxy. Exam tip: Global HTTP(S) LB is most common for web apps, know when Network LB needed.

cards.vocab: What is Private Google Access and Private Service Connect?
cards.meaning: Private Google Access และ Private Service Connect คืออะไร?
cards.example: Private Google Access (PGA): Access Google APIs from VMs without external IPs. Enable per subnet. Routes traffic to Google APIs internally. DNS: private.googleapis.com or restricted.googleapis.com. Private Service Connect (PSC): Private endpoints in your VPC for Google services or your own services. Types: 1) Access Google APIs: Dedicated IP in your VPC. 2) Published services: Expose your service privately. 3) Consumer endpoints: Access partner services. Benefits over PGA: 1) Dedicated IP (not shared). 2) Firewall rules work on the endpoint. 3) No DNS complexity. 4) Works across VPC peering. Exam tip: PGA for simple needs, PSC for enterprise requirements (dedicated IPs, firewall control).

cards.vocab: How do you implement network security on GCP?
cards.meaning: Implement network security บน GCP อย่างไร?
cards.example: Layers of security: 1) Perimeter: Cloud Armor (DDoS, WAF), reCAPTCHA Enterprise. 2) Network: VPC firewall rules, hierarchical firewall policies, network tags. 3) Application: Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP), API Gateway authentication. 4) Data: VPC Service Controls, Private Google Access. Firewall best practices: 1) Default deny ingress. 2) Use service accounts for rules (not tags). 3) Hierarchical policies for organization-wide rules. 4) Log firewall rules for audit. Zero-trust approach: 1) BeyondCorp Enterprise. 2) IAP for application access. 3) VPC Service Controls for API perimeter. 4) Workload Identity for service-to-service. Exam tip: Know Cloud Armor capabilities, VPC Service Controls for data exfiltration prevention.

cards.vocab: How do you design DNS for GCP environments?
cards.meaning: ออกแบบ DNS สำหรับ GCP environments อย่างไร?
cards.example: Cloud DNS zones: 1) Public zones: Internet-resolvable domains. 2) Private zones: Internal resolution within VPCs. 3) Forwarding zones: Forward queries to on-prem DNS. 4) Peering zones: Share DNS across VPCs without peering. Hybrid DNS patterns: 1) GCP → On-prem: Forwarding zones or DNS peering. 2) On-prem → GCP: Inbound DNS policy (create DNS server IPs in VPC). Split-horizon DNS: Same domain, different records internal vs external. Example: api.company.com → internal LB (private) vs external LB (public). Best practices: 1) Use private zones for internal services. 2) DNSSEC for public zones. 3) Consistent naming conventions. 4) Use forwarding for on-prem integration. Exam tip: Know private zones, forwarding zones, split-horizon patterns.

cards.vocab: What is Cloud CDN and when should you use it?
cards.meaning: Cloud CDN คืออะไร และควรใช้เมื่อไหร่?
cards.example: Cloud CDN: Global content delivery network. Features: 1) Edge caching at 100+ edge locations. 2) Integrated with Global HTTP(S) LB. 3) Cache static and dynamic content. 4) Signed URLs/cookies for access control. 5) Cache invalidation API. Use cases: 1) Static websites and assets. 2) Software downloads. 3) Video streaming. 4) API response caching. Configuration: Enable on backend service/bucket. Cache modes: USE_ORIGIN_HEADERS, CACHE_ALL_STATIC, FORCE_CACHE_ALL. Cache keys: Default (URI), custom (headers, cookies, query params). Cost: CDN egress cheaper than standard egress. Exam tip: Know cache modes, when to use signed URLs, cache key customization.

cards.vocab: How do you implement network segmentation?
cards.meaning: Implement network segmentation อย่างไร?
cards.example: Segmentation strategies: 1) Subnet-based: Different subnets for tiers (web, app, db). Firewall rules between subnets. 2) Project-based: Separate projects for environments or teams. Use Shared VPC or peering. 3) VPC-based: Separate VPCs for high isolation. Connect via peering or VPN if needed. GKE segmentation: 1) Namespace isolation. 2) Network Policies (pod-to-pod rules). 3) Private clusters (no public IPs). 4) Authorized networks (API server access). Micro-segmentation: Service-to-service firewalling using service accounts. Example: Only frontend SA can reach backend SA. Best practices: 1) Least privilege network access. 2) Segment by sensitivity level. 3) Use tags or service accounts for rules. 4) Log and monitor traffic. Exam tip: Know firewall rules with service accounts, GKE Network Policies.
